Award.AwardTitle: A Neurocomputational investigation of developmental visual recognition disorders

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One outstanding question in the visual sciences is how different types of visual stimuli are recognized and processed. Humans rely heavily on vision and much of the cerebral cortex in involved with processing visual information. This project examines how adults recognize two classes of visual objects, faces and words, which on the surface seem rather different but may actually share some of the same underlying processes. The work also explores what goes wrong in individuals who have greater than typical difficulties with recognizing faces or words, arising from developmental or congenital problems. To address this, the investigators will explore both the behavioral skills and the brain systems involved in visual recognition of faces and words, in normally skilled individuals and in who have difficulty with face recognition or with word recognition.

This research is highly significant for a number of reasons. First, the research has the potential to contribute to our broad understanding of the brain and the processes that permit normal face and word recognition. Second, new techniques, software and analytical methods for measuring the brain and behavioral processes will be developed, and these new methods will be made available to other scientists and can be applied to studying other cognitive abilities, as well. Third, the studies will provide a better understanding of the processes that are affected when someone has difficulty learning to read or to recognize faces and thus may point to improved techniques for the diagnosis and remediation of such developmental deficits. Fourth, the project offers the opportunity for students to be trained in the field of cognitive neuroscience and to develop skills that will allow them to become independent scientific investigators in future. Finally, the investigators will use the research to teach middle school students about the brain and infuse them with an interest in scientific discovery from an early age.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was designed to evaluate theoretically and empirically the hypothesis proposed that faces and words emerge from the same underlying computations. The crux of the claim is that both faces and words are visual categories in which the exemplars are highly similar. This homogeneity requires fine-grained visual acuity to discriminate between the exemplars and thus the representation of these two classes compete for cortical loci which permit pattern recognition but occupy the anterior extrapolation of the fovea. However, because words and faces are so dissimilar in image space, and because visual word representations should be more left-hemisphere lateralized so as to be coupled to left hemisphere language systems in the modal right-hander, face representations are shifted more (but not exclusively so) to the right hemisphere (Behrmann & Plaut, 2013, 2014, 2015).

                  We conducted extensive behavioral and electrophysiological studies that show that adults show the typical left hemisphere (LH) superiority for word processing and right hemisphere (RH) processing for face stimuli. Adolescents and children only show the LH advantage for word processing and the emergence of face lateralization was correlated with reading competence. These findings suggest that the hemispheric organization of face and word recognition are interdependent and that the earlier word lateralization may drive the later face lateralization (Dundas, Plaut, & Behrmann, 2013, 2014).

                  We also demonstrated that those individuals who have atypical language lateralization do not show this pattern and this includes left-handed individuals (Dundas, Plaut, & Behrmann, 2015) as well as individuals with developmental dyslexia (Collins, Dundas, Gabay, Plaut, & Behrmann, under review; Gabay, Dundas, Plaut, & Behrmann, 2017). These individuals show atypical hemispheric organization for both word recognition and face recognitions. In contrast individuals with a different neurodevelopmental disorder, congenital prosopagnosia, in whom word recognition is preserved, do not show the alteration in hemispheric organization for words but do evince an atypical pattern for hemispheric organization of face recognition (Collins et al., under review).

                  Together, these findings support the theoretical view that hemispheric organization emerges from a number of constraints namely, the pressure for proximity between language and high resolution visual areas in the LH with the resultant shift of face representations to the RH. The joint enterprise of computational modeling and empirical studies permitted simulating the relevant behavioral conditions and comparisons and these simulations offered predictions for follow-up studies.
